what: 1. Navigating the Codification of the Political Administrative Division of Colombia (DIVIPOLA)
title: Analyzing demographic data with epiCo
text: DIVIPOLA standardized nomenclature designed DANE identification territorial entities (departments, districts, municipalities), non-municipalized areas, populated centers assigning unique numerical code territorial units. Colombia : 32 Departments (Administrative Division Level 1) 1102 Municipalities (Administrative Division Level 2) 1 Island 18 Non-municipalized areas 6678 Populated centers Two digits used codification departments, five digits used codification municipalities (first two department located). epiCo provides complete list departments municipalities codes built-dataset.
code: library(epiCo) library(incidence)  data("divipola_table")

title: Analyzing demographic data with epiCo
text: epiCo provides built-dataset population projections Colombia national, departmental, municipality levels (provided DANE). datasets contains population projections 2012 2024 ages 0 100 years. However, municipal projections ages 0 85 years old. Users can perform queries data using population_pyramid function, providing DIVIPOLA code territory interest year consult. Definitions age ranges plotting also provided : total number individuals, proportion individuals
code: ibague_code <- "73001" # DIVIPOLA code for the city of Ibagu<U+00E9> year <- 2016 # Year to consult ibague_pyramid_2016 <- population_pyramid(ibague_code, year) # Population # pyramid (dataframe) for the city of Ibagu<U+00E9> in the year 2019 # dissagregated by sex head(ibague_pyramid_2016) #>   age population sex #> 1   0      15839   F #> 2   5      17539   F #> 3  10      20171   F #> 4  15      23059   F #> 5  20      22659   F #> 6  25      20685   F ibague_code <- "73001" # DIVIPOLA code for the city of Ibagu<U+00E9> year <- 2019 # Year to consult age_range <- 5 # Age range or window ibague_pyramid_2019 <- population_pyramid(ibague_code, year,   range = age_range,   sex = TRUE, total = TRUE,   plot = TRUE, language = "EN" )

title: Analyzing demographic data with epiCo
text: Events epidemiological relevance reported SIVIGILA using official notification form (see link). epiCo provides function consult dictionaries ethnicity categories, special population groups, occupation codifications used SIVIGILA.
code: demog_data <- data.frame(   id = c(0001, 002, 003, 004, 005, 006, 007),   ethnicity_label = c(3, 4, 2, 3, 3, 3, 2),   occupation_label = c(6111, 3221, 5113, 5133, 6111, 23, 25),   sex = c("F", "M", "F", "F", "M", "M", "F"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Description of ethnicities describe_ethnicity(demog_data$ethnicity_label, language = "EN") #>   code #> 1    2 #> 2    3 #> 3    4 #> identity; They are characterized by a nomadic tradition, and have their own language, which is Romanesque #> 2 Population located in the Archipelago of San Andres, Providencia and Santa Catalina, with Afro-Anglo-Antillean cultural roots, whose members have clearly differentiated sociocultural and linguistic traits from the rest of the Afro-Colombian population #> 3 a Creole language # reported in the consulted dataset describe_occupation(   isco_codes = demog_data$occupation_label,   sex = demog_data$sex,   plot = "treemap" ) # Description of the occupations #> 1codes are invalid. #> $data #>   major                                        major_label sub_major #> 1     5 Service Workers and Shop and Market Sales Workers         51 #> 2     5 Service Workers and Shop and Market Sales Workers         51 #> 3     6          Skilled Agricultural and Fishery Workers         61 #> 4     2                                     Professionals         23 #> 5     3 NA #>                                             sub_major_label minor #> 1                 Personal and Protective Services Workers    511 #> 2                 Personal and Protective Services Workers    513 #> 3 Market-Oriented Skilled Agricultural and Fishery Workers    611 #> 4                                   Teaching Professionals     NA #> 5          Life Science and Health Associate Professionals    322 #> 6 Market-Oriented Skilled Agricultural and Fishery Workers    611 #> 7                                                      <NA>    NA #> and Crop Growers  6111 #> 4                                                    <NA>   NA #> 5 Modern Health Associate Professionals (Except Nursing)  3221 #> 6                      Market Gardeners Field crop and vegetable growers     M     1 #> 7                              <NA> <NA>     1 #>  #> $plot # reported in the consulted dataset

title: Analyzing demographic data with epiCo
text: epiCo tool produces analyses based epidemiological data extracted SIVIGILA provided user. epi_data built-file shows example structure used package, one reported SIVIGILA. file contains cases municipalities Tolima years 2015-2021. following analyses use dengue cases reported Tolima 2019.
code: data("epi_data")  data_tolima <- epi_data[lubridate::year(epi_data$fec_not) == 2019, ] head(data_tolima) #> # A tibble: 6 × 16 #>   fec_not    cod_pais_o cod_dpto_o cod_mun_o cod_pais_r cod_dpto_r cod_mun_r #>   <chr>      <chr>      <chr>      <chr>     <chr>      <chr>      <chr>     #> 1 2019-01-02 170        73         73001     170        73         73001     #> 2 2019-01-15 170        73         73268     170        73         73268     #> 3 2019-01-01 170        73         73200     170        73         73200     #> 4 2019-01-12 170        73         73671     170        73         73671     #> 5 2019-01-05 170        73         73671     170        73         73671     #> 6 2019-01-05 170        73         73671     170        25         25754     #> # ℹ 9 more variables: cod_dpto_n <chr>, cod_mun_n <chr>, edad <dbl>, #> #   sexo <chr>, per_etn <dbl>, ocupacion <chr>, estrato <chr>, ini_sin <chr>, #> #   cod_eve <dbl>

title: Analyzing demographic data with epiCo
text: incidence rate feature epiCo requires incidence package produce modified incidence object. Instead count vector (matrix), transforms object provide rate element accounting number cases time period divided total number inhabitants specific region year. epiCo uses DANE population projections denominators; therefore, necessary provide administration level incidences calculated. groups incidence object within DIVIPOLA coding municipalities (level 2) departments (level 1), national estimation intended (level 0), function able estimate incidence rate.

what: 6. Estimation of risk by age group
title: Analyzing demographic data with epiCo
text: Normalization data key aspect epidemiology. epiCo allows age distribution cases normalizes epidemiological data age structure population. normalization allows us estimate age risk disease according age structure general population municipality, department, country certain year.
code: data_ibague <- data_tolima[data_tolima$cod_mun_o == 73001, ]  age_risk_data <- age_risk(   age = as.integer(data_ibague$edad),   population_pyramid = ibague_pyramid_2019$data,   sex = data_ibague$sexo, plot = TRUE, language = "EN" )

title: Building an Endemic Channel with epiCo
text: Using endemic channel visual strategy represent historical behavior disease specific region epidemic curve defines central tendency cases year upper lower limits cases expected vary. plot provides three lines known “\(\color{green}{\text{Safety}}\)”, “\(\color{orange}{\text{Warning}}\)”, “\(\color{Red}{\text{Epidemic}}\)” bands (Figure 1), later used define epidemiological situation region based current (observed) cases. broader definition methodology endemic channel provided Bortman (1999).  data needed build endemic channel weekly monthly incidence disease previous years region interest. epiCo asks least one year data, endemic channels typically estimated 5 7 years information. natural presume years provide better estimations since statistical analyses robust, important contextual information ensure transmission, surveillance, demographic conditions (among factors) changed period time. Regarding frequency data, weekly incidence may provide useful information disease behavior moment epidemiological warning raised; however, experience users, context, whether resolution data can achieved. Another common decision building endemic channel ignore previous epidemic years avoid misrepresenting traditional transmission dynamics. epiCo suggest epidemic years automatically, endemic_channel function provide option annotate outlier years decide whether include, ignore, adjust . data-gathering tips sources provided later vignette.

title: Building an Endemic Channel with epiCo
text: statistical summary disease behavior, endemic channel provides central tendency measure (CTM) describe typical value historical data. Since nature epidemiological data tends normal, typically used CTM endemic channels geometric mean. CTM known better represent expected value data set skewed distribution /susceptible outliers (previous outbreaks). endemic_channel function uses geometric mean default CTM, arithmetic mean median can chosen according user’s experience context. important note geometric mean performs multiplication data, zero cases reported moment time, estimation leads zero CTM. avoid , epiCo’s endemic_channel function performs shift data sum one case (default value) observations, subtracts shift final calculation. avoid random selection shift, users can ask endemic_channel function find optimal value based de la Cruz & Kreft (2019), can also ask use weighted method described Habib (2012). Finally, endemic_channel function can perform Poisson test (unusual behavior method) historical data requested user taking account pertinence test, since mostly used scenarios diseases low incidence records. method uses arithmetic mean CTM.

title: Building an Endemic Channel with epiCo
text: upper lower limits endemic channel provide confidence interval used define epidemiological bands previously described. epiCo’s endemic_channel function following preset limits according selected CTM: Arithmetic geometric mean CTM: mean +/- t value 95% CI multiplied variance data number observations. Median CTM: quantiles 0.25 0.75 lower upper limits, respectively. Poisson test (unusual behavior method): limits provided two-sided Poisson test 0.95% CI

what: 2. Historical data needed to build an endemic channel
title: Building an Endemic Channel with epiCo
text: section provides strategies obtain, handle, gather historical data needed build endemic channel. presumes user either line list incidence data disease interest need consult historical data Colombian National Surveillance System (SIVIGILA). Regardless user´s case, goal section create incidence object historical data disease. object must account incidence single region (groups allowed endemic_channel function), must weekly monthly interval (epiweeks also allowed), must represent least one year information. broader understanding incidence package, please refer vignettes.

previous_headings: 2. Historical data needed to build an endemic channel
what: Historic incidence from the line list or SIVIGILA data
title: Building an Endemic Channel with epiCo
text: endemic channel useful data immediate previous year available; however, always possible users outside surveillance institutions. option, users can access SIVIGILA’s line list data typically published second semester year (.e., data 2022 published second semester 2023). example, data provided data folder package used. data present data dengue cases municipalities Tolima years 2015 2021. case, use cases municipality Ibagué calculate respective endemic channel. users line list data, goal : clean handle data build incidence object (named incidence_historic previous example). key message list dates account event interest needed later used incidence package.
code: library(epiCo) library(incidence)  data("epi_data") data_event <- epi_data  data_ibague <- data_event[data_event$cod_mun_o == 73001, ]  ## Building the historic incidence data  incidence_historic <- incidence(data_ibague$fec_not,   interval = "1 epiweek" )  knitr::kable(incidence_historic[1:5, ])

previous_headings: 2. Historical data needed to build an endemic channel
what: Setting up the data from incidence information
title: Building an Endemic Channel with epiCo
text: Future versions epiCo’s endemic_channel function allow users import table accounting periods time (weeks months) count cases, specific information dates case, endemic channel can still built.

title: Building an Endemic Channel with epiCo
text: gathering incidence data, users ready ask epiCo build endemic channel. endemic_channel function following parameters: incidence_historic: incidence object case counts previous years observations: numeric vector current observations (default = NULL) method: string mean calculation method preference (“median”, “mean”, “geometric”) “unusual_behavior” method (Poisson Distribution Test) (default = “geometric”) geometric_method: string selected method geometric mean calculation (see epiCo’s geometric_mean function) (default = “shifted”). outlier_years: numeric vector outlier (epidemic) years (default = NULL). outliers_handling: string handling decision regarding outlier years: ignored = data outlier years taken account (default). included = data outlier years take account. replaced_by_median = data outlier years replaced median taken account. replaced_by_mean = data outlier years replaced mean taken account. replaced_by_geometric_mean = data outlier years replaced geometric mean taken account. ci: numeric value specify confidence interval use geometric method (default = 0.95). plot: boolean displaying plot (default = FALSE). output epiCo’s endemic_channel function dataframe observation, historical mean, confidence intervals, plot displaying four epidemiological bands, current observations (provided), methods outliers handling set user.

title: Building an Endemic Channel with epiCo
text: following example uses previously historic incidence accessed SIVIGILA data source build 2021 endemic channel Ibagué City.
code: observations <- sample(5:40, 52, replace = TRUE)  outlier_years <- c(2016, 2019)  ibague_endemic_chanel <- endemic_channel(   incidence_historic = incidence_historic,   observations = observations,   method = "geometric",   outlier_years = outlier_years,   plot = TRUE ) #> Data after2022-12-25 were not used for the endemic channel calculation.

title: Building an Endemic Channel with epiCo
text: endemic channel visualization tool stratify epidemiological situation region. instructions gather, process interpret results responsibility governmental institutions. communication results typically done framework risk assessment, early warning protocols, epidemic response leaded public health officers. important adjust use epiCo official guidelines implemented.

what: 1. Real travel times among Colombian municipalities
title: Spatiotemporal analyses with epiCo
text: Several approaches estimating proximity neighborhood point (region) developed literature. rely euclidean distances among centroids areas, whereas others rely contiguity approaches boundaries. epiCo aims propose new approach neighborhood estimation defining proximity among municipalities based real available infrastructure territory. important countries like Colombia, topology shapes connectivity interaction municipalities Euclidean distances boundaries may lead overestimation nearness reality one three mountain ranges one several rivers country may lead large travel distances times. estimate real travel times among Colombian municipalities, travel times matrix calculated based Bravo-Vega C., Santos-Vega M., & Cordovez J.M. (2022) study. travel times account fastest path connect one municipality municipalities friction map provides different speeds according presence quality roads, fluvial transport, walking possibilities.

title: Spatiotemporal analyses with epiCo
text: Since epiCo stores travel times among municipalities Colombia, definition neighborhood based expertise knowledge user regarding maximum travel time municipality considered neighbor. neighborhoods function receives parameters vector DIVIPOLA codes accounting municipalities consider potential neighbors threshold accounts maximum travel time (hours) municipality can another.
code: library(epiCo) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(incidence) data(divipola_table) cundinamarca_data <- dplyr::filter(   divipola_table,   NOM_DPTO == "CUNDINAMARCA" ) %>%   select(COD_MPIO, LATITUD, LONGITUD)  cundinamarca_neighborhood <- neighborhoods(   query_vector = cundinamarca_data$COD_MPIO,   threshold = 0.5 )$neighbours #> Municipalities 25572, 25653, 25885 are not part of the neighborhood according to the selected thershold in hours. It wil be displayed as 'Not significant' but it was not included in the local moran's index analysis. plot(cundinamarca_neighborhood, cbind(   cundinamarca_data$LATITUD,   cundinamarca_data$LONGITUD ))

title: Spatiotemporal analyses with epiCo
text: epiCo provides function perform Local Moran’s index analysis incidence object unique observations set Colombian municipalities. Internally, function reads incidence object’s groups DIVIPOLA codes : Estimate incidence rates using epiCo’s incidence_rate function. Evaluate epiCo’s neighborhoods function. necessary user provide travel time threshold neighborhood definition. following example uses cases municipalities Tolima year 2019.
code: data("epi_data")  data_tolima <- epi_data[lubridate::year(epi_data$fec_not) == 2019, ] incidence_object <- incidence(   dates = data_tolima$fec_not,   groups = data_tolima$cod_mun_o,   interval = "12 months" )  morans_tolima <- morans_index(incidence_object = incidence_object,                               language = "ES") #> Significant municipalities are:  #> 73024 with Low-High (incidence - spatial correlation) #> 73226 with High-High (incidence - spatial correlation) #> 73555 with High-High (incidence - spatial correlation) #> 73675 with High-High (incidence - spatial correlation) morans_tolima$plot

what: 4. Interpretation and communication of epiCo’s morans_index results
title: Spatiotemporal analyses with epiCo
text: High-high clusters represent areas high incidence rate surrounded areas high incidence rates, suggesting spatial cluster elevated risk (e.g., disease hotspot). Similarly, low-low clusters indicate areas low incidence rates surrounded low incidence rates areas. High-low low-high clusters represent areas dissimilar values neighboring may lead significant conclusions regarding spatial behavior disease. Nevertheless, important recall cluster map (one created epiCo’s morans_index function) complementary tool understand spatiotemporal behavior disease, limited provide explicit information regarding (example) allocation resources. Comparisons methodologies epidemiology experience done address epidemic responses. addition, risk communication share simple interpretable results. public opinion may misleaded confused clusters analysis, simpler visualization disease behavior heatmaps used.

what: Statistical and Visualization Tools for the Analysis of Outbreaks of Vector-Borne Diseases (VBDs) in Colombia
title: Statistical and Visualization Tools for the Analysis of Outbreaks of Vector-Borne Diseases (VBDs) in Colombia
text: epiCo provides statistical visualization tools analysis demographic indicators, spatio-temporal behavior characterization outbreaks vector-borne diseases (VBDs) Colombia.

title: Statistical and Visualization Tools for the Analysis of Outbreaks of Vector-Borne Diseases (VBDs) in Colombia
text: can install development version epiCo GitHub :
code: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("epiverse-trace/epiCo")

title: Statistical and Visualization Tools for the Analysis of Outbreaks of Vector-Borne Diseases (VBDs) in Colombia
text: reviewing current epidemiological bulletins published local Secretariats Health Colombia, identified opportunity create tool : - Include spatial demographic risk assessments routine epidemiological reports better identify population groups potential interventions. - Facilitate understanding different epidemiological profiles within region Colombia regarding onset, duration, magnitude, frequency outbreaks. - Strengthen transparency methods used outbreak analysis. - Provide informative context performing spatial correlation analysis. package allows interoperable analyses linelist data SIVIGILA (accessible using Epiverse-TRACE package sivirep) spatial demographic data (accessible using Epiverse-TRACE package ColOpenData). epiCo can used perform following main tasks municipality, departmental, national level: identify demographic vulnerabilities linelist data socioeconomic census, including risk assessment based age, gender, occupation, ethnicity. assess hot-spot analyses (Local Moran’s index) based real travel distances Colombia estimated Bravo-Vega C., Santos-Vega M., & Cordovez J.M. (2022). generate automated outbreak characterization (onset, duration, magnitude, frequency) using traditional methods endemic channel poisson tests unusual behavior. Future features include correlation analyses categorical socioeconomic data, climate time series epidemiological data, nowcasting assessment, underreport estimation, short-term forecasting. features performed automatically epidemiological, demographic, spatial, socioeconomic data published Colombian institutions, methods can also customized well input data, hypothetical information can tested within package.

title: Statistical and Visualization Tools for the Analysis of Outbreaks of Vector-Borne Diseases (VBDs) in Colombia
text: epiCo contains three modules documented following vignettes: Demographic analyses epiCo Building Endemic Channel epiCo Spatiotemporal analyses epiCo

title: Statistical and Visualization Tools for the Analysis of Outbreaks of Vector-Borne Diseases (VBDs) in Colombia

Umaña (author) Juan Montenegro-Torres (author) Julian Otero (author) Hugo Gruson (contributor) Mauricio Santos-Vega (advisor) Catalina Gonzalez Uribe (advisor) Juan Manuel Cordovez (advisor) acknowledge contribution collaborators Universidad de los Andes, Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Instituto Nacional de Salud de Colombia, Secretaría de Salud del Tolima, Epimodelac Course attendees provided insightful feedback package.

title: Create and return the endemic channel of a disease from an incidence object — endemic_channel

title: Modifies the historic incidence to handle with the observations of epidemic years — endemic_outliers

title: Modifies the historic incidence to handle with the observations of epidemic years — endemic_outliers

what: Returns the geometric mean of a vector of real numbers. — geometric_mean
title: Returns the geometric mean of a vector of real numbers. — geometric_mean
text: Function returns geometric mean vector real numbers according selected method.

title: Returns the geometric mean of a vector of real numbers. — geometric_mean
code: geometric_mean(   x,   method = c("positive", "shifted", "optimized", "weighted"),   shift = 1,   epsilon = 0.001 )

title: Returns the geometric mean of a vector of real numbers. — geometric_mean
text: x numeric vector real values method Description methods: positive = positive values within x used calculation. shifted = positive zero values within x used adding shift value calculation subtracting final result. optimized = optimized shifted method. See: De La Cruz, R., & Kreft, J. U. (2018). Geometric mean extension data sets zeros. arXiv preprint arXiv:1806.06403. weighted = probability weighted calculation gm negative, positive, zero values. See: Habib, E. . (2012). Geometric mean negative zero values. International Journal Research Reviews Applied Sciences, 11(3), 419-432. shift = 1 (default) positive value use shifted method epsilon = 1e-5 (default) minimum positive value consider optimized method.

title: Returns the geometric mean of a vector of real numbers. — geometric_mean
text: geometric mean x vector, epsilon value optimized method used.

title: Returns the geometric mean of a vector of real numbers. — geometric_mean
code: x <- c(4, 5, 3, 7, 8) geometric_mean(x, method = "optimized") #> [1] 5.07565 0.03967

See: De La Cruz, R., & Kreft, J. U. (2018). Geometric mean extension data sets zeros. arXiv preprint arXiv:1806.06403. weighted = probability weighted calculation gm negative, positive, zero values. See: Habib, E. . (2012). Geometric mean negative zero values. International Journal Research Reviews Applied Sciences, 11(3), 419-432. shift positive value use shifted method delta positive value (shift) used optimized method.
